Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: SusChEM: Investigating the Structure-Property Relationships of Sugar-Derived Block Copolymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The aim of this proposal is to design and study novel materials from sugar-derived natural resources that would have special molecular architectures and properties. Such properties would include tunable, temperature-responsive behavior in water solutions. The materials will consist of different types of polymers linked together ("block copolymers") whose two components can have different molecular architectures, molecular lengths, chemical structures, etc. The effects of all these parameters will be investigated on the self-assembly of these molecules and on the structure-property relationships of the resulting materials. The major outcomes of this research effort may lead to new paradigms for polymer design, synthesis, and self-assembly through the use of highly abundant natural resources. Additionally, the project includes a major focus on educational and outreach activities. The team of investigators will collaborate with the Institute for School Partnership of Washington University to develop outreach and education activities for underrepresented and underprivileged students in the St. Louis community.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The long-term research goal of this project is to enable technologies for the design and synthesis of high-performance and renewable polymeric materials that exploit various sugars produced by lignocellulosic cell-wall carbohydrate depolymerization. Sugars obtained from lignocellulose represent an abundant and renewable feedstock that potentially could reduce reliance on petroleum-based resources. To this end, the PIs will design and synthesize renewable sugar-derived block copolymers (BCP) that exhibit tunable temperature-responsive behavior in aqueous solution. Specific aims will involve developing tailorable BCPs from designer, sugar-derived, and stereo-specific monomers through controlled polymerization; then examining the self-assembly and structure-property relationships associated with the design of solution-assembled amphiphilic BCPs for tunable and temperature-responsive solution applications. Design parameters to be explored include: pendant topological structure (i.e., linear vs. branched sugar derivative); pendant chemical structure (i.e., hydrophobicity and hydrophilicity); block volume fractions and compositions; and overall molecular weight. The project is integrated with a strong educational and outreach component aimed at broadening participation of underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Meeting rising global manufacturing and energy demands while minimizing associated externalities and liabilities can be accomplished only through a combination of behavioral shifts and the continued discovery and application of sustainable technologies.  In line with this reality, research efforts that focus on routes toward the generation of renewable polymers, and ultimately sustainable materials, are paramount.  A biorefinery facilitates an integrated conversion process and efficiently utilize the materials and energy locked within lignocellulosic biomass.  A broader impact of this proposal addresses part of the challenges related to the increased value-added utilization of high-throughput biorefinery intermediates.  Several such high-throughput intermediates in a biorefinery are glucose and other monosaccharides (e.g., arabinose, mannose, galactose, etc.) that result from depolymerization of cell wall polysaccharides within lignocellulosic biomass.  These sugars from biomass are an attractive feedstock for polymeric materials production, based on their abundance, low-cost, and ease of functionalization.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The objective of this project was to understand the properties of renewable sugar-derived polymeric materials that exhibit the tunable ability to change its properties in response to temperature.  We synthesized several polymers with building blocks derived from mannose and glucose, examining their polymer behavior in solutions.  We discovered that the mannose-derived building block was capable of transforming from oil-loving to water-loving in water when the temperature was elevated.  As a consequence, a polymer partly composed of the mannose-derived building blocks displayed a critical temperature transition point at which its structure and size dramatically changes.  In addition, by post-polymerization chemical modification of the mannose-derived building blocks, we were ability to tune this critical temperature transition point.  Having the ability to control the temperature at which polymers change solution behavior are useful in polymeric systems for drug delivery, separations, nano-reactor applications, among others.    Key results were highlighted in oral and poster presentations to the scientific community and manuscripts in preparation.

 

Broader Impact:

During this project, a number of outreach activities were conducted.  At Washington University in St. Louis, two “Researcher for a Day” workshops were organized, offering an opportunity to inform, inspire, and motivate local underrepresented minority middle school students through a campus visit and lab demonstrations.  We have had 52 6-8th students from Hawthorn Leadership School for Girls in St. Louis attend (May 6, 2016 and March 31, 2017).  The “Researcher for a Day” program allows young students to visit a university setting and envision themselves on campus and in the labs.  Through hands-on experiments, this workshop emphasized the development of innovative routes for utilizing biomass to sustainably meet future global demand of polymers.  At the University of Delaware, as part of the annual College of Engineering K-12 outreach summer camp 2016, we hosted 20 elementary school students and 20 middle school students to teach them about biomimicry and stimuli responsive materials.  We discussed chromatophers in the skin of some cephalopods with stimuli responsive color change capability.  We also demonstrated this concept using two types of natural halochromic compounds, turmeric and red cabbage juice, to show how color can change with pH.  In addition, two undergraduate students from University of Delaware and one REU student from Case Western Reserve University worked in the lab and were mentored by a postdoctoral researcher during the summer of 2016 and 2017, researching the polymerization of bio-based polymeric materials.
